head.title: The Clubs. A Satire.11 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 10-12; reprinted in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 15, 1796). Robert Crawford has recently contrasted Turnbull’s conclusion here that he will “gladly sing / That loyal song ‘GOD SAVE THE KING!,” with the political ambiguity of Burns’s conclusion to his song “The Dumfries Volunteers," that “While we sing God save the King, / We’ll ne’er forget the People!” (Crawford, The Bard [Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2009], p. 385; Poems and Songs, ed. Kinsley, 3 vols. (Oxford: Clarendon, 1969), II: 764-765, III: 1469). In December 1792, a riot had broken out in the Dumfries Theatre when radicals in the audience called for singing the French revolutionary song “Ça ira,” while hissing “God save the King”: see Letters of Robert Burns, ed. G. Ross Roy, 2 vols. (Oxford: Clarendon, 1985), II: pp. 166, 173.

lg.l: Now jowing bells, with solemn croon,
Proclaim another day is done,
And fowk wha due decorum keep,
Forget their cares in silent sleep;
While jovial sauls that fear nae ill,
Keep up the noise and riot still.
Loud rings the tavern but and ben,
With men turn’d sots, and sots turn’d men.
Here, may we see a drunken core,
That can do nought but sing and roar;
Ane, ocean fu’ of nappy liquor,22 n. strong ale.
Lilts at auld Moses and the Vicar;
A fat guidman, at the board head,

Laments John Barlycorn33 Personification of the barley crop and character in a popular British ballad. Countless variants of the song exist, including Burns’s “John Barleycorn: A Ballad” first published in 1787, but written earlier (Kinsley, I:29-31). is dead;
Ane, the maist jovial of the quorum,

Cries “damn ye! gie me Tullochgorum.”44 Strathspey that can be traced back to 1734 in the Duke of Perth MS. The dance tune gained popularity when Reverend John Skinner wrote lyrics to accompany it. First published in Weekly Magazine, or, Edinburgh Amusement (May, 1776) and later included in the Scots Musical Museum, 3 (1787), song 289.
And here, a Counsellor, hum drum,
Sits sweetly tuning “ti, ta, tum!”
Tam, wi’ the bottom of a cap
Comes o’er his nose a cursed rap;
A Bully, snoring at his side,
Starts up and swers he’ll skelp his hide;
Out o’er he reels, and in his fa’,
Breaks table, glasses, bowls an’ a’!
Another room a group contains
Of busy, cloud’environ’d brains;
A set of Politicians, who
Direct the course of things below:
All Europe’s fate depends on them,
Baith Indies their attention claim.
Poor Louis’ cause55 Louis XVI (1754-1793), King of France at the time of the French Revolution, was deposed in 1792 and executed January 1793. is fairly try’d,
With warm debates on either side.
There twa, whas brows portend a storm,
Sit busy planning a reform.
Here ane, his Liege’s firmest friend,
Swears he’ll the government defend.
Another, vows his resolution
Is, to o’erturn the constitution.
A chap, mair noisy than the rest,
Declares he likes the——what is’t, best?
And swears, by blood, and death, and hell—
He kens what he would do himsel’!
Whilst others, at a less expence,
Are counted miracles of sense;
Important looks, and shrugs, and hitches,
Do mair than twenty learned speeches!
Let those, my friends, delight in noise,
Incapable for social joys;
Let these ’bout politics debate,
And regulate both kirk and state:
With us let all disputes be ended;
The times by words will ne’er be mended.
My principle, if I dare mention;—

I’m sworn a foe to the Convention.66 The Scottish radical group the Friends of the People, founded in July 1792, held three National Conventions in Edinburgh before its leaders, including the lawyer Thomas Muir of Huntershill, were arrested for sedition and sentenced to transportation.
I’ll honour Freedom while I live,
But, such as British laws can give!
And though not able to defend
My Liege, my aid I’d freely lend:
And while I’ve breath I’ll gladly sing
That loyal song, “GOD SAVE THE KING!”
